units.title: Dissociation and digestion
units.text:
1. Turn on rotating oven and allow it to heat up to 37 °C while you prepare your sample.
2. Obtain a 60 mm cell culture dish containing ~7 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
3. Add 150 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) to each dish.
4. Obtain ~250 mg of human brain tissue per sample. Document case details.
5. Place in dish containing HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase.
6. With a scalpel, cut tissue into small (~2 mm × 2 mm chunks) in HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase solution in a sterile environment (Fig. 2).
7. Distribute tissue into three 15 mL conical tubes.
 • Aliquot the tissue–buffer solution in the dish into the tubes first
 • Use extra HBSS/BSA/glucose buffer to wash the dish and make up to 5 mL per tube
8. Add 167 µL of collagenase/dispase (100 mg/mL) to each tube. Please note, 167 µL of collagenase/dispase per 5 mL is equivalent to 33.4 µL of solution per 1 mL.
9. Digest for 30 min in rotating oven at 37 °C.
units.rationale: Prepares tissue for downstream cell isolation.

units.title: Percoll density gradient centrifugation
units.text:
11. After samples have finished spinning, discard the supernatant by pouring out the liquid into a waste container.
12. Add 1 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and 50 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) into each sample tube.
13. Gently mix/resuspend 50 times using a micropipette, taking care not to introduce bubbles, which may detrimentally affect the cells49.
14. Obtain two additional 15 mL conical tubes per each sample tube. For example, for three sample digestion tubes, obtain six tubes for Percoll filtration.
15. Dispense 4 mL of 22% Percoll into each new conical tube.
16. Carefully dispense cell suspension from each sample tube into the new conical tubes containing 22% Percoll in equal amounts. Use ~750 µL per tube.
17. Spin down for 10 min at 500g, 4 °C with no deceleration.
18. Discard supernatant.
19. Reunite contents of all Percoll tubes into one tube by resuspending the cell pellet in the HBSS/BSA/glucose remaining after pouring out the supernatant.
20. Spin down the sample tube for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
21. Do not discard the remaining tubes. The small amount of cells left over after combining the majority of cells into one tube for the master mix can be used for unstained and DAPI controls (Steps 36–45).
units.rationale: Separates viable cells from debris using a density gradient.

units.title: Master mix preparation
units.text:
22. Add 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose into a fresh tube.
23. Add 2 µL of each antibody and 1 µL of DAPI into the tube containing 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose per sample.
units.rationale: Creates a staining cocktail for immunolabeling.

units.title: Immunostaining
units.text:
24. After samples have finished spinning, discard supernatant.
25. Resuspend in ~200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
26. Add the master mix into the tube of resuspended cells.
27. Incubate for 15 min on ice. During this sample incubation, start preparing controls by following Steps 36–45.
28. Wash with 5 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and mix.
29. Spin down for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
30. Discard supernatant.
 • Note the amount of supernatant remaining in the tube; 500 µL of supernatant is needed to resuspend
 • Add additional HBSS/BSA/glucose if below the recommended 500 µL needed to resuspend
31. Resuspend cells.
32. Obtain one FACS tube and a 70 µm filter.
33. With the filter over the FACS tube, dispense the resuspended cells through the filter and into the FACS tube.
34. Seal the tube and place on ice.
35. Take samples to FACS.
units.rationale: Labels cells with fluorophore-conjugated antibodies for flow analysis.

units.title: Control (cell) tube preparation
units.text:
36. Obtain the three leftover 15 mL tubes after combining sample contents into one tube (Step 19).
37. Sequentially, rinse each tube with ~500 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and combine into one tube.
38. Obtain six fresh FACS tubes and fresh 70 µm filters.
39. With the filters on top of the FACS tubes, dispense 250 µL of combined buffer rinse into two of the FACS tubes.
40. Proceed to Step 41.
units.rationale: Prepares cell‑based control samples for flow cytometry.

units.title: Control (beads) tube preparation and immunostaining
units.text:
41. Dispense 250 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose into each of the four remaining FACS tubes.
42. Add 2.5 µL of a single antibody to each single-color control tube into the FACS tubes containing 250 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
43. For the live/dead stain, add 1.25 µL of DAPI into the FACS tubes containing 250 µL of combined buffer/cell rinse. One tube will be unstained.
44. After adding antibodies as explained in Step 43, shake the UltraComp eBead vial and add one drop of beads to each single-color control with the ‘Ready to Use’ bottle.
45. Seal the tubes and place on ice.
units.rationale: Generates bead‑based single‑color controls for compensation.

units.title: FACS
units.text:
46. Set the laser levels for each of your fluorophores with unstained and single-color controls.
47. Once the laser levels are set, then run the single-color controls again to record each fluorophore. After every single-color control has been run, the machine can perform compensation, the method of correcting for fluorescence spill over.
48. Once the laser levels are set and compensation performed, the user can draw gates to select sequential populations (Fig. 3a). For this strategy, we recommend first eliminating debris with side scatter (SSC) and forward scatter (FSC) gates.
49. Next, eliminate doublets also with SSC or FSC.
50. Eliminate dead cells. We use DAPI but a number of live/dead stains exist in different fluorophores.
51. After eliminating debris, doublets and dead cells, then the user should set up FACS plots to select their population of interests. In our studies, endothelial cells were isolated as CD45−CD31+ANPEP− and mural cells were isolated as CD45−CD31−ANPEP+.
52. (Optional) Run additional controls to determine the true population. These may include ‘fluorescence minus one’ controls and unstained controls.
53. After the population has been defined, use a 100 µm nozzle to perform cell sorting.
units.rationale: Sorts labeled cells into pure populations for downstream use.

units.title: Collagen coating
units.text:
56. Obtain a 24-well plate.
57. Calculate the amount of collagen coating solution needed. We recommend 500 µL of collagen coating solution (0.03 mg/mL) per well.
58. Add 500 µL of collagen coating solution (0.03 mg/mL) into each well.
59. Incubate plate with collagen for 30 min at 37 °C.
60. After incubation, remove collagen coating solution from all wells.
61. Wash wells once with 1× PBS and then they are ready to use (if not using immediately, keep PBS in the wells and store in 37 °C incubator until the sorted cells are ready to be plated).
units.rationale: Prepares culture surface to promote cell attachment.

units.title: Plating
units.text:
62. Spin down sorted mural and/or endothelial cell tubes (from Step 54) by centrifuging for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
63. After spinning, remove supernatant from microcentrifuge tubes containing cells.
64. Add 500 µL of prewarmed (37 °C) growth medium into microcentrifuge tubes containing mural or endothelial cell pellets.
65. Resuspend.
66. Add the desired amount of cell solution into collagen-coated wells. We recommend filling each culture well with cell solution to approximately half volume.
67. Add additional 500 µL of growth medium into wells containing cells for 1 mL total per well.
68. Add 500 µL of 1× PBS to all other empty wells to keep them from drying.
69. Place in a 37 °C incubator.
units.rationale: Seeds isolated cells onto coated plates for culture.

units.title: Cell transplantation
units.text:
96. Collect mural and/or endothelial cells sorted in Step 54.
97. Immediately after sorting, infect the cell population of interest with AAV–CMV–GFP. Mix the cell solution thoroughly using a pipette. We use 1 µL (stock titer of 1 × 10^13 GF/mL; 200 multiplicity of infection (MOI)) for 50,000 cells. Place cells at 37 °C for 30 min.
98. To avoid viral leakage into the organoids, wash cells three times with 1× PBS, each time spinning down at 300g for 5 min at 4 °C.
99. Select organoids for transplantation. Preferred organoids should display spherical shape and clear edges without any cell debris. Organoids vary in size, so a variety of organoid sizes will be used within a given experimental condition; ensure that you distribute different sizes across conditions.
100. Using a wide-opening pipette tip, move number of desired organoids onto Millicell culture inserts in a 6-well flat-bottom plate. Transwells help prevent the organoid from moving as the vascular cells are incorporated during the transplants. We recommend three to six organoids per condition.
101. Immediately before adding cells, gently remove as much medium surrounding the organoids within the well as possible using a p1000 pipette.
102. Gently add desired amount of cells on top of the organoids and incubate at 37 °C for 30 min.
103. After incubation, gently add medium to well insert until the organoid floats off of the insert, ~3 mL.
104. Maintain organoids in a 37 °C incubator. The transwell can be removed the day after transplantation. After transplantation, maintain the organoids submerged in medium.
units.rationale: Introduces labeled vascular cells into brain organoids for integration studies.
